meta.content: Pekin CSD - Update to Families on School Closure 4-17-2020

Communication - 4/17/2020
Pekin Families,
WOW - Today we found out that the Governor announced that all schools in Iowa will remain closed through the end of the school year to help prevent the further spread of COVID-19. We have many unanswered questions and I ask you to be patient as we develop plans.
This announcement will continue...

div.em: Current conditions as of 29 Apr 11:15 am CDT

div.div: A 50 percent chance of showers, mainly before 5pm. Cloudy, with a high near 56. Breezy, with a north wind around 25 mph, with gusts as high as 40 mph. New precipitation amounts of less than a tenth of an inch possible.

A 10 percent chance of showers before 7pm. Mostly cloudy during the early evening, then gradual clearing, with a low around 44. Breezy, with a northwest wind 15 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph.
Sunny, with a high near 67. Breezy, with a northwest wind 15 to 20 mph, with gusts as high as 30 mph.

div.div: Your session will expire in 0 minutes.

div.h3: Update to Families on School Closure 4-17-2020

p.b: WOW - Today we found out that the Governor announced that all schools in Iowa will remain closed through the end of the school year to help prevent the further spread of COVID-19. We have many unanswered questions and I ask you to be patient as we develop plans.

This announcement will continue to impact all Pekin Community School District programming, including before- and after-school activities, all athletic and extracurricular practices and competitions, and all weekend events. It is our hope that we will be able to keep Prom as scheduled in June and develop a plan for graduation, but we do not yet know how these events will look. We do want to make these events special for our students so we are working at developing something unique.

I know this decision has caused a great deal of concern and disappointment for our students, staff, and families. The pandemic arrived quickly, and when we first were directed to close our school buildings in March, we did not realize it would be the last time we would see our students in person this school year. Please know that we share in your disappointment.

Per our district calendar, the last day of school for students is Friday, May 22. We will continue with virtual learning until that date, just as we have over the past several weeks. We encourage all families to keep their students engaged in these activities to ensure learning continues to take place through the end of the school year. Our staff is ready to assist all families in these efforts, as well.

I want to make sure families understand not to get stressed over being thrusted into a home school position. I do not want you to feel overwhelmed with work being sent by the teacher. Please remember this is not required so if you are getting frustrated, please back off - You have my permission. The work is designed to ensure they are staying connected with school and the materials being covered in each of their classrooms. We know in the bigger scheme of life, this might not need to be a priority for families. We want you to take care of yourself and your family. Like I said before, we will work our tails off to get ALL kids caught up when we get them back to school.

We want our families’ to be engaging students in the learning resources we have provided and we know everyone is doing their best. We ask you to continue to do your best so our students are doing something from March 15 to August 24, but use common sense. This will ensure they are somewhat prepared to be successful next school year. Our staff is here to help you bridge this gap till we get them back into the classroom.

We will continue school lunch services through the extended school closure, as well. Currently, we are delivering meals on Mondays and Wednesdays. These deliveries ensure meals for each school day through May 22 when our USDA funding will run out.

Once again, thank you for your patience, understanding, and flexibility during this unprecedented time. We will get through this together. Please continue to stay safe, practice social distancing, and keep our community in your thoughts and prayers. It is going to take a while for our families and communities to get back to normal, so please continue to lean on each other. If you have questions, please feel free to call me on my cell at 641-224-2524.
